title: 104_hr1126
content: The Act titled "Durham Woods Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1995" increases inspection requirements in high-density population areas. The "Durham Woods Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1995" mandates more frequent inspections for gas pipelines, requiring internal inspections every 7 years and monthly observations of surface conditions on and around the right-of-way. The "Durham Woods Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1995" requires regular inspections of gas transmission pipeline facilities for leaks, construction issues, and safety concerns. Line markers must be placed along the rights-of-way unless impractical. SEC. 3. DAMAGE REPORTING. Amends Section 60123(d)(2) of title 49, United States Code to include reporting requirements for damage to pipeline facilities. SEC. 4. INCREASED PENALTIES. Amends criminal penalties in title 49, United States Code to increase penalties for violations. Amends civil penalties to increase fines for violations. The text increases criminal penalties in title 49, United States Code by raising fines from $500,000 to $1,000,000 and from $50,000 to $100,000. SEC. 5 amends Section 60116 of title 49, US Code to require the Secretary to make grants to States for promoting public awareness of excavating near pipeline facilities. The Secretary of Transportation will conduct a study on the safety of gas transmission pipeline facilities in New Jersey, addressing population encroachment, environmental concerns, financial pressures, and the use of shut-off valves. A report will be submitted to Congress within a year. The Secretary of Transportation will assess risks related to gas transportation by pipeline, ranking them by probability and severity. Actions to reduce risks will be identified and prioritized, including inspection by internal devices, leak detection systems, and underwater pipeline inspection and burial. The Secretary of Transportation will assess risks related to gas transportation by pipeline, including inspection and replacement of cast iron pipelines. A report to Congress with the assessment and proposed actions to address identified risks must be submitted within 18 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 8. MAPPING. Section 60102 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to require the owner or operator of gas transmission or hazardous liquid pipelines to inform the Secretary of their specific locations. The Secretary will then develop a comprehensive mapping program to identify the locations of all pipeline facilities and gathering lines, considering proximity to high-density population areas and environmentally sensitive areas. The Secretary will establish an electronic data base for a comprehensive mapping program to identify pipeline locations, ensuring its availability to State and local governments and the public. Security measures will be implemented to protect the program against terrorism and other threats. SEC. 9. TECHNICAL SAFETY STANDARDS COMMITTEE. Amends Section 60115(f) by removing the first 2 sentences and adding "of a committee under this section" after "A member". SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. Terms in this Act have the same definitions as in section 60101 of title 49, United States Code.
